facts.text: Deputy Superintendent of Central Excise at Bharatpur received information that Sulled and his son Rehman had cultivated tobacco but had not paid excise duty thereon.
On September 9, 1953, at 2 p.m., Deputy Superintendent accompanied by Inspector, sepoy, chowkidar and two motbirs went to Rehman's house to search for stored tobacco.
When they declared intention to search, respondent (Rehman) and Dhamman allegedly obstructed, causing Deputy Superintendent to fall and receive injuries.
Respondent and Dhamman prosecuted under s. 353 IPC; Munsif-Magistrate discharged Dhamman but convicted Rehman and sentenced to 3 months RI.
On appeal, Additional Sessions Judge held search not conducted per s. 165 CrPC and remanded for fresh enquiry.
On remand, Munsif-Magistrate found search by Deputy Superintendent without recording reasons under s. 165 CrPC, held obstruction of illegal search not offence, acquitted respondent.
High Court confirmed acquittal on September 20, 1957.
State preferred appeal to Supreme Court by certificate under Art. 134(1)(c).
Respondent's counsel did not appear before Supreme Court.

legal_issues.text: Whether searches under r. 201 of Central Excise Rules must comply with s. 165 CrPC (recording reasons) or only s. 103 CrPC, as the search was to gather information for excise duty, not prosecution.
Whether recording reasons under s. 165 CrPC is merely procedural or jurisdictional, given power derives from r. 201.

petitioner_arguments.text: Act, Rules and CrPC distinguish power to search from manner; here search to quantify tobacco for duty, not investigation for prosecution, so follow s. 103 CrPC generally, not s. 165 for police investigation.
petitioner_arguments.legal_basis: Central Excise and Salt Act s.18; CrPC s.103, s.165; Central Excise Rules r.201

petitioner_arguments.text: Even if s.165 applies, it confers power/jurisdiction to search with procedure; recording reasons relates to jurisdiction, but excise officer's power from r.201, so only follow procedural part.
petitioner_arguments.legal_basis: CrPC s.165; Central Excise Rules r.201

petitioner_arguments.text: Even if reasons not recorded, it is mere irregularity; respondent had no right to prevent search.

court_reasoning.text: Under s.18 Act, searches under Act/Rules carried out per CrPC provisions on searches; r.201 authorizes search where reason to believe excisable goods contravene Act/Rules, which is offence under s.9, so akin to investigation.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Searches under r.201 approximate police searches under s.165 during investigation of cognizable offence.

court_reasoning.text: s.165 imposes conditions including recording grounds of belief; comparable to r.201 searches; s.18 mandates compliance with appropriate CrPC provisions, so s.165 fully applies to r.201 searches.
court_reasoning.key_observation: No reason for safeguards under s.165 for police but not for excise officers.

court_reasoning.text: Recording reasons does not confer jurisdiction (power from statute), but is essential condition; ignoring it means search not per CrPC provisions as required by s.18 Act.
Third contention (irregularity only, no right to resist) not raised earlier, not allowed now.

holdings.text: Provisions of s.165 CrPC must be followed for searches under r.201 Central Excise Rules.
Recording reasons under s.165 is essential condition, not merely procedural; non-compliance renders search illegal.

statutes_cited.name: Central Excise and Salt Act, 1944
statutes_cited.relevance: Regulates searches (s.18 mandates CrPC compliance), offences, duties on excisable goods including tobacco.

statutes_cited.name: Code of Criminal Procedure
statutes_cited.relevance: Governs manner of searches; s.165 applies to r.201 searches, requires recording reasons.

statutes_cited.name: Indian Penal Code
statutes_cited.relevance: Charge of assault/obstruction to public servant.

outcome.summary: Supreme Court upheld High Court and trial court's acquittal of respondent under s.353 IPC, holding the search illegal for non-compliance with s.165 CrPC (no reasons recorded), so no offence in obstruction.

key_quotes.text: We therefore hold that the provisions of s. 165 of the Code must be followed in the matter of searches under r. 201 of the Rules.
key_quotes.speaker: court
key_quotes.significance: Core holding on applicability of s.165 CrPC to excise searches.

key_quotes.text: The recording of reasons is an important step in the matter of search and to ignore it is to ignore the material part of the provisions governing searches.
key_quotes.speaker: court
key_quotes.significance: Explains why non-recording renders search illegal.

key_quotes.text: As search is a process exceedingly arbitrary in character, stringent statutory conditions are imposed on the exercise of the power.
key_quotes.speaker: court
